Dear Ms. Klinski:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violation, report why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION:
Youth was restrained on 8/20/21 and 8/23/21. Restraint was not uploaded to
MiSACWIS for 8/20/21. Appropriate review of restraints is not occurring by the
facility. There are concerns related to the justification for the restraint.
3

INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received on 08/25/21 after information was received by DCWL
alleging possible rule and contract noncompliances.
In an email from Youth A’s worker on 08/25/21, the worker reported a number of
concerns with the facility. The following summarizes the email from Youth A’s
worker. The worker reported that Youth A was involved in an incident where he
accessed inappropriate pornography websites via the new onsite school program’s
tablet on Thursday, 08/19/21. The worker said that the therapist told her that the
next day, 08/20/21, Youth A was in an altercation with a peer. The worker said that
based on the incident report she received, the incident with the peer occurred on
8/23/21. The worker said that she reviewed the report with Youth A who provided his
account of what occurred. The youth reportedly told his worker the following:
He was watching TV and had a cup of water in his hand. The other youth tried to
scare him from behind and it caused Youth A to spill his water on him. He stated
that he got up and threw the rest of the water on the kid and was walking to his
room to get paper towels and he jokingly hit the kid with a notebook and was
laughing about the incident. The other peer didn’t think it was funny and punched
him in the side of the head on the right side. He also said that both him and the
other youth threw chairs at each other but did not make impact. No marks or
swelling. He was seen by the nurse and no meds or treatment was needed.
Youth A’s worker went on to note that Youth A’s consequence for accessing the
pornography was to take away his library privileges which upset him because
reading is his number one coping skill. Reportedly, the facility took all of the books
that the worker and Youth A’s court advocate purchased him away and only let him
have one book that was in the unit. It was also reported that Youth A was banned
from the gym due to the incident with the peer and the IPad.
Youth A’s worker added that he told her that on 8/24/2021, Youth A was upset again
that he could not go to the library, and he said:
Staff was “taunting him” about not being able to get books and it upset him so he
threw a chair and a trash can. He said that he sat down at the table to calm down
and Facility Manger 1 (FM1) was in his face telling him to calm down and trying
to get him to tell him why he was mad and Youth A stated that he asked him two
times to back up and let him calm down and FM1 didn’t do that so he threw the
mayonnaise in his face. He said FM1 instantly put him in a physical restraint and
told him to calm down. Youth A stated that he calmed down and went to his
room. He said that he was checked out by the nurse and no treatment was
necessary.
The worker stated that she received an email from the Therapist on 08/23/21 and
also received a voice message from someone at the facility (did not leave a name)
4

notifying her of the restraint. The worker said that she tried to call Lincoln Center and
was told by whoever answered the phone that Youth A is not able to have phone
calls. The worker said that she explained that she is his worker and that they can’t
refuse to allow her contact to Youth A. The staff reportedly told the worker to call
back the next day and talk to his therapist/case manager and hung up on the worker.
The worker said that she called back, and it went to voicemail. The worker said that
she also contacted Youth A’s attorney, who also tried to call, and they sent him to
voicemail. Youth A’s worker then said she emailed his case manager and asked for
a phone call and was able to speak to Youth A on 08/24/21, but his case manager
was present, and he was not able to talk freely. The worker said that Youth A had
told her prior that he is afraid to talk because he doesn’t want retaliation. Youth A’s
worker said that she told the case manager about her attempted phone contact with
Youth A the night prior and was told that youth can’t have contact for 48 hours after
an incident and that she was not sure who was working when the worker tried to call.
The worker said that Youth A stated that they are not able to call their workers or
attorneys without a therapist present. The worker said that she reiterated that Youth
A should be able to contact his attorney or worker if he needs to talk to them and
she again stated it is only when a therapist is available. The worker said this was not
the first time she experienced this and that she went to the facility to speak directly
with Youth A in that instance.
The worker added that she met with Youth A on 08/25/21 and Youth A reported:
They are short staffed and not getting their group services (anger management
or sexual reactive programming) and that sometimes they don’t get their weekly
therapy if their therapist is gone (Therapist). He reported that he has not heard or
seen anything that has occurred in other units because they are not allowed to
talk or look at others in the other units, but he reported that in his unit, staff and
peers get along for the most part, very few incidents occur, but a Supervisor
instigates a lot of verbal disagreements in the unit. Youth A didn’t go into detail
about how often, but it mainly focuses on telling the youth that they have to share
their thoughts with each other and some of the youth do not like to share and it
causes a disruption but not like the referral stated about staff being physical with
them.
He reported that he does feel safe in his pod and that his entire pod just stays
away from the other pods because they get into a lot of trouble and they have
their own issues in their pod they don’t need other people’s issues. Youth A was
advised of his right to file a grievance if he feels his rights are being violated or if
he tries to call me or his attorney and they refuse. He stated that they are not
allowed to file them and that the grievance box has been down for months. He
stated that a youth that was there previously kicked it off the wall and they put in
the closet and never hung it back up. He is looking forward to finishing his
program and getting out of Lincoln Center.
5

The worker added that she will not be violating Youth A on his probation. The worker
said that she thinks there is a lot of information missing in the incident reports and it
appears that Youth A has taken responsibility and was able to identify what
happened, what he could have or should have done, so she didn’t feel a violation
was warranted.
In additional emails from Youth A’s worker, on 08/27/21, it was reported that Youth A
had an appointment outside of the facility and that he was brought to the
appointment in a stained orange jumpsuit and shackled around his waist and feet,
and in handcuffs. The worker said that she requested that he be brought in his court
clothes and didn’t understand why he had to be shackled as he is able to go off
campus with his workers without being shackled. Per the doctor’s request, the
shackles and handcuffs were removed. The security staff reportedly told the doctor
that if Youth A runs, then the doctor and his staff can chase him, because they were
not going to. Youth A’s worker said that Youth A, “did great during the entire day.”
The worker added that during the assessment he disclosed that he has had suicidal
ideation and that, although she had some difficulty getting in touch with the facility to
follow up, the Director told her they would put him on suicide prevention and bring in
the psychiatrist for evaluation. The worker further said that the Director told her that
their policy is if the youth leaves the facility with their staff that they are shackled at
the waist and feet and handcuffed, but if they are with a worker or attorney they don’t
have to be because he is in other’s care. The Director also told the worker that a
plan needed to be worked out for the court clothes and she advised him that we
have discussed this several times and that he needs to be in court clothes for his
appointments. Reportedly, the Director said the “clinical staff” didn’t tell them or else
he could have worn them.
I met with Director 1 onsite on 08/26/21, to discuss the incident and review the
video. Upon initial review of this incident, I noted the concern over physical
management being used due to the youth throwing mayonnaise at FM1 and
concerns related to the manner in which Youth A was transported. Director 1 said
that he agreed and would have to address that with the staff.
Video review of this incident:
The video began with Youth A, peers, and staff, including FM1, on the pod. Youth A
was observed in an escalated and agitated state. Youth A was seen throwing
various items, including books, dumping garbage out, and slamming and kicking
doors. The staff and FM1 appeared to be giving Youth A space to vent his anger and
didn’t respond to his outburst. At about 12:31:17, Youth A tossed mayonnaise at
FM1, getting it on FM1’s face. FM1 walked toward Youth A who walked away from
FM1. FM1 put hands on Youth A by grabbing Youth A’s arms from behind him, in an
apparent attempt to put the youth in a restraint hold. At about 12:31:24 the two
moved under a camera and out of view. They return to view at about 12:31:37 and
were seen walking along the wall with FM1 holding Youth A from behind by the back
of his jumper. FM1 was also seen grabbing Youth A over Youth A’s shoulder near
his neck from behind. Youth A continued to avoid the restraint hold by pressing his
6

right side and shoulder into the wall. Staffs 2 and 3 approached and Staff 3 assisted
FM1 by grabbing Youth A’s left arm and holding Youth A by the back of his jumper.
FM1 and Staff 3 then push Youth A forward and into his bedroom while Youth A
struggled with them. They entered the room about 12:31:52. The video skipped from
about 12:31:56 until 12:32:09 and the two staff exited the room at 12:32:11.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 08/26/21. Youth A reported the following
related to the allegations and the additional information provided by his worker.
Youth A said that in regard to the iPad incident, it was the new school program’s
iPad, and they have since locked the websites he accessed. He said that he
received 5 days of loss of his “greens” (privileges). After that incident, Youth A said
he got into the fight with the peer. Youth A described the incident very similar to how
he reported it to his worker (noted above). Youth A said that the peer scared him
from behind which caused Youth A to jump and spill water on himself. Youth A said
he then threw the rest of the water on the peer and then hit the peer in the head with
a notebook and walked to his bedroom. The peer then hit him in the head when he
was walking away, which led to both youth throwing books/chairs at one another.
Youth A said, “I accept that he hit me. I went too far.” Youth A said that his
consequence for this was that he lost his library privileges. Youth A said that this
consequence was added to his loss of greens so that he didn’t permanently lose his
level and have to go up for it again and said that the staff kind of helped him out by
doing this. He said that he did not lose gym privileges, he just doesn’t choose to go
because he doesn’t like it. The other peer lost gym because he likes gym. Youth A
said that he only had one book for one day but got another 10 or more books the
next day. Youth A said that a peer brought from the library for him. He said there are
other books on the pod that he had access to, but only one that he had not read yet.
Youth A also confirmed that there are also books in the treatment room that he could
have accessed.
Youth A said that on the day of the restraint, which was 08/23/21, he was still upset
about the library restriction consequences and was acting out, slamming doors, and
throwing things on the pod. Youth A said that he also grabbed a mayonnaise packet
and squirted/threw it on FM1 and was then restrained and pushed against the wall.
Youth A said he was then dragged to his room. Youth A said that he did not recall
what staff it was, but someone helped FM1 get him into his room. Youth A reported
no injury during this process. He said that he did see the nurse later on.
Youth A reported that in regard to his treatment, Youth A does get anger
management and sexual reactivity therapy, but more of the anger management
treatment topics. He reported individual therapy occurs once weekly and they always
do their sessions. Youth A recalled one time that the individual session was missed,
but he said it was made up with two sessions the next week. Youth A did note that
they are not doing group therapy regularly.
Youth A said that if residents are restrained, they are not allowed to talk to workers
because “kids say things they don’t mean.” Youth A said that time is so the youth
7

can calm down. Youth A also stated, “My worker doesn’t agree, but I understand it.”
Youth A said that for some calls with workers, there is a therapist there to monitor it.
Youth A was able to identify that if he had a problem or concern with a restraint or if
he was hurt, that he would tell someone. When asked who he would tell, he said he
would probably tell the nurse.
I interviewed the Facility Manger (FM1) at the facility on 08/31/21. The manager was
asked about this restraint. We reviewed the video and FM1 said that he initiated the
physical management because Youth A kept escalating and was throwing garbage.
FM1 said that they moved other kids to the treatment room so staff could focus on
Youth A. FM1 said that he continued to talk to Youth A to verbally deescalate him,
but he kept banging on doors and threw books toward FM1. FM1 said that they
continued to give Youth A space to vent and time to calm down and they started
getting ready for lunch. FM1 said that when Youth A squirted mayonnaise on FM1’s
face and in his eye, FM1 initiated the restraint because Youth A was then being
physically aggressive and “lashing out at actual people.” FM1 said that he did not
know what Youth A was going to do next.
I asked FM1 about the other concerns reported by Youth A’s worker. FM1 said that
he did not know anything about phone calls being prohibited for 48 hours after a
restraint. In regard to the iPad, FM1 said that he heard about it but was not there
during that incident and was not involved in the consequences. FM1 said that a loss
of “greens” or level privileges would be warranted in a case like that as the youth
was not meeting level expectations. Behaviors like this would also be processed via
individual therapy, group sessions, thinking work/assignments as part of how the
youth earn their level back. In regard to the altercation with the peer, FM1 said that
he was there and saw that. FM1 reported that removal of library privileges is a
typical type of consequence as is loss of merit points. The consequence was added
on, but they “cut him a break so he didn’t lose his level totally.” FM1 said that youth
have group sessions daily.
I interviewed the Therapist on 09/09/21 at the facility. The Therapist reported being
assigned to work with Youth A since July 2021. The Therapist reported that the
school discovered Youth A had accessed pornography on one of the iPads. Due to
this, Youth A received a five-day level drop. The incident was processed in therapy
the following week when the Therapist saw Youth A again. Youth A was also
provided a rational thinking assignment. The Therapist said that she is not facilitating
group sessions at this time, because she is only covering for another therapist who
is on maternity leave. This group of youth is being split between three therapists to
cover for the maternity leave. The Therapist said that she does group with her
regularly assigned youth, but only individual sessions with the youth she is covering.
In regard to the incident with a peer, the Therapist said that she was not clear on the
details of the full incident. She said that therapists get consequence forms when
there is an incident, but not the incident reports. The Therapist said that additional
consequences such as, removal of library privileges, is typical. When Youth A was
restrained, the Therapist said she was notified by FM1. The Therapist said that FM1
8

told her that Youth A’s behaviors escalated because he couldn’t go to the library,
and he began throwing books and garbage. Then Youth A picked up food and
squirted mayonnaise in FM1’s eyes. Additionally, the Therapist confirmed that there
are books available on the pods for the youth. In regard to the phone calls, the
Therapist said that she was not aware of any 48-hour restriction on phone calls after
an incident. The Therapist said that youth would be able to have a call as long as
they were not in seclusion for something. The Therapist said that workers can speak
with kids, but they cannot simply call up to the pod and talk to them; callers have to
be verified and scheduled. Supervisors and Managers have to coordinate calls as
youth have to be brought up to the visitation rooms where there are phones for them
to use.
I conducted an unannounced visit on 10/13/21 and walked onto Youth A’s pod (Pod
A) to find Youth A and his peers in group therapy with the Therapist.
I interviewed Staff 2 at the facility on 10/25/21. Staff 2 appeared displeased with
having to meet about this incident. Staff 2 recalled this incident and said that the
whole issue was on Youth A and that Youth A was acting like “a real ass.” Staff 2
said they tried to give Youth A space and deescalate him, but he wasn’t responding.
Staff 2 said that the staff didn’t do anything wrong. Staff 2 said that he did not recall
if he participated in any part of the escort of Youth A and stated that he did not know
Staff 3.
An attempt was made to contact Staff 3 via phone, as he is a contingent staff and
not scheduled regularly, but his phone was not in service.
I met with Director 2 on 10/25/21 at the facility. Director 2 reported that the facility
does not have a policy related to youth’s use of electronics.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
 Incident Report for the 08/20/21 incident with Youth A and his peer. It was
noted that Youth A and a peer engaged in a verbal dispute and were directed
to cease the conversation. The two ignored the staff direction and threw water
on each other. The peer assaulted Youth A by striking him in the face and
both youths picked up their chairs and tossed them at one another. The
Security officer stepped between them, and their actions stopped. Both youth
utilized time outs until they were able to regain self-control.
 Incident Report for the 08/23/21 restraint of Youth A. Authored by FM1 and
submitted to MiSACWIS by FM2. The report was consistent with the interview
of FM1.
 Unusual Incident Report Witness Statement, dated 08/23/21, authored by
Staff 2. Marked for Resident Assault on Staff. The report reads, “Resident
was off focus and was throwing around objects. He was physically managed
escorted to room.”
 Unusual Incident Report Summary, dated 08/23/21, authored by FM1 and
approved by Director 1.
9

 Medical Progress Note, 08/23/21, by the Nurse. No injuries or concerns.
 Youth Discipline Policy
o Continued Negative Behaviors (includes)
 Possession of contraband: possession of any unauthorized
articles or materials including possession of pornography or
attempting to obtain pornography.
 Threatening the safety of others/Intimidating or Bullying
o Consequences for Continued Negative Behaviors
 Staff will also select one or two of the following consequences:
 1. A loss of free time recreation privileges for 3 days.
 6. Temporary return to Level One Merit System
Privileges for 5 days.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.159 Resident restraint.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies
and procedures regarding restraint. These policies and
procedures shall be available to all residents, their
families, and referring agencies.
(3) The written policy shall include all of the following:
(a) Procedures for the review of an incident of restraint
within 48 hours by a level of supervision above the
staff ordering or conducting the restraint to
determine if the requirements of the institution’s
procedures were adhered to in directing and
conducting the restraint.
(4) The written policy shall only permit the licensee to
restrain a child for the following circumstances:
(a) To prevent injury to the child, self-injury, or injury to
others.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule as Youth A’s behaviors,
although escalated, did not present an immediate risk of injury
to anyone. The staff were observed providing space for Youth A
until Youth A squirted the mayonnaise on FM1. This does not
qualify as justification for physical restraint. Additionally, FM1
was observed on the video review to not use proper Handle with
Care technique during the escort to Youth A’s room. FM1 was
observed with his arm over Youth A’s shoulder at one point and
grabbing the back of Youth A’s jumper as well. Staff 3 was also
observed grabbing Youth A by the back of his jumper. The two
staff pushed Youth A into his bedroom. An escort is permitted
but the youth must be walking on their own and not being forced
to move while resisting, as occurred in this instance. The staff
should have put Youth A in a proper two person standing
10

restraint until he was cooperative to walk. Additionally, this
restraint incident report was completed by FM2 and should have
been reviewed prior to submission. If proper review had
occurred, the non-compliances could have been addressed by
the facility.
There is no finding that the facility did not upload a restraint, as
Youth A was not restrained in the 08/20/21 incident.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

APPLICABLE Contract
RFCJJ 2.10 Services to be Provided
a. Trauma Informed Practice Model
1) Services provided under this Contract must be trauma
informed and be evidence-based, evidence-informed or
identified as a promising practice to effect optimal
outcomes.
ANALYSIS: It was alleged and confirmed the facility brought Youth A to
court in a jumpsuit. While this did occur, there is no explicit
requirement to not do so.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
The facility was provided Technical Assistance verbally and via
email related to not sending youth into the community in their
facility jumpsuits as this is not an example of a therapeutic
action on the part of the facility. The facility can provide court
clothes for the youth for outside appointments or other suitable
attire, in an effort to provide a more therapeutic and caring
environment, given these are children in a treatment facility and
not a correctional institution.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
11

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of
the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for
addressing residents’ needs, implementation of
treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: The facility does not have a policy pertaining to the use of
electronics by youth.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
The facility is advised to ensure they develop a policy or
procedure for monitoring the youth’s use of electronics. This
should apply to use of school equipment and recreational
devices, such as video games.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
The youth is not receiving required therapy services.
INVESTIGATION:
See interview content above.
Documentation reviewed:
Sample of therapy notes for Youth A from a 10-week period of July through mid-
September. The Therapist’s note for 07/23/21 was copied and pasted from the
07/14/21 note, including the date of service as 07/14/21. The Therapist’s note from
09/03/21 indicated the therapist would be out of the office for the week. Group
sessions are summarized each weekly entries and they note that the youth is
expected to attend group sessions five times a week, Monday through Friday. Seven
of the ten weeks only had this statement and no documentation of group topics,
whether the sessions were done, and/or whether the youth participated.
12

APPLICABLE Contract
RFCJJ Attachment A: Residential Foster Care Juvenile Justice
Program Types
1. Mental Health and Behavior Stabilization
Services
f. Individual, Group and Family Therapy
i. Both individual and group therapy are requirements
of this Contract. At least two times per week, the
Contractor must provide direct therapeutic
interventions for each youth individually and/or in
group sessions. At least one session per week must
be an individual therapy session. Individual and/or
group therapy must be provided in accordance with
the youth’s treatment needs as identified in the
youth’s service plan.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the contract as the Therapist
acknowledged that this group was not getting group therapy.
Additionally, there is not sufficient documentation of provision of
required therapy sessions. In a review of a sample of individual
therapy notes, it was found that no individual therapy was
documented for two of the ten weeks. Also, the notes for group
sessions are vague and do not provide sufficient detail to verify
that group sessions occurred daily (per the facility’s protocol)
and whether the specified youth participated. This
documentation supports the Therapist’s and Youth A’s reports of
group sessions not always occurring.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

ALLEGATION:
Youth A reported that he is not allowed to, nor has a way to file a grievance.
INVESTIGATION:
Youth A’s worker reported that Youth A told her he was not allowed to file a
grievance and that the grievance box on the pod was down.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 08/26/21. Youth A reported that a former
resident ripped the grievance box off of the wall on their pod and it was never put
back up. Youth A stated that the residents now tell a manager if they have a concern
and named three Facility Managers, including FM1, whom they can tell. Youth A
said that FM1 and another manager listen and are good about responding, but he
felt the third manager forgets things a lot. Youth A stated that if he had a “major”
concern, that he would also report it to his worker, but would go to the managers
first.
On 08/31/21, I walked through Youth A’s pod and other pods at the facility with FM1.
The grievance box on Youth A’s pod was observed to be missing. The grievance
box on another pod was smashed to the degree that it appeared inoperable.
I interviewed FM1 on 08/31/21 at the facility. FM1 said that the grievance boxes do
get knocked down by the youth but should be put back up. He noted that he would
follow up to see that it was reinstalled.
In subsequent meetings with the Chief Administrator, it was reported that they
installed folders on those pods with missing and/or damaged grievance box for youth
to use for grievance forms. I observed this to be completed during a weekly
unannounced visit to the facility as well.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
 Youth Grievance Policy
A. Step 1: Youth may request to speak with a Shift Supervisor regarding a
grievance or ask for a grievance form and write the complaint down. After
completing the grievance form, youth will place it in one of the
“confidential” locked boxes provided on each pod.
15

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4132 Grievance procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow a written grievance handling
procedure for residents and their families. All of the following
apply:
(a) The policy shall be provided to residents, their families,
and referring sources prior to or at admission.
(b) The policy shall be explained in a language the resident
and his or her family can understand.
(c) There shall be written acknowledgement the policy was
provided as required in subdivision (a) of this subrule.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation as they are not following their policy for
written grievances. The grievance box on Youth A’s pod was
observed to be missing, leaving the youth with no confidential
place to submit grievance forms. On another pod, the grievance
box was observed to be smashed in so much that it appeared
that a grievance form would not be able to be put in the box. I
also recommended to the Chief Administrator that, although the
folders are a good temporary solution, the facility must return to
the use of the secure metal boxes to comply with their policy
and ensure resident confidentiality.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current 3rd
provisional license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility
submitting an acceptable CAP for the noted violations.
